In such a case, there are as many separate obligations as there are debitores, hut the object oi all these obligations is the same: each debtor is, therefore, liable ior the whole object, or liable in solidum (as distinct stom the liability pro parte exemplified by a joint promise to pay 15l.), but as the object is only one, it can only be once attained, and therefore performance by one oi the joint debtors releases the rest. This is called solidary obligation: and as two or more debtors can be solidarily bound to one creditor (passive solidarity), so two or more creditors can be solidarily entitled against one debtor (active soli- darity); ie. either or any one oi them can, without consulting the other or rest, claim the whole object (which forms the connecting linlr between the different obligations) from the single debtor 3 butas soon as he has done what he has to do ior one, the vinculum iuris between him and all is severed, and he is free. The predominance oi passive over active solidary obligationis so great that some writers have supposed the latter to have no real existence.
